text: Hey, I come from Python, where actually using the language to do anything is discouraged, modules handle all the heavy lifting, and minimizing dependencies is important for interoperability.  I know that Julia was designed with the opposite intent but can‚Äôt shake the feeling that I should use packages, avoid objects, and keep my code in pure Julia for simplicity and performance.

elements.text: Hey, I come from Python, where actually using the language to do anything is discouraged, modules handle all the heavy lifting, and minimizing dependencies is important for interoperability.  I know that Julia was designed with the opposite intent but can‚Äôt shake the feeling that I should use packages, avoid objects, and keep my code in pure Julia for simplicity and performance.

text:
Hello and welcome!
Very broad question. I do think it's correct minimizing dependencies has advantages for maintainability and interoperability, although my experience is that maintaining Julia is quite a bit easier than Python, because of the better package manager of Julia. The Julia ecosystem have more packages that are small, well-tested and built to synergize with other packages, and fewer giant monolith packages like Numpy or Scipy

elements.text:
Hello and welcome!
Very broad question. I do think it's correct minimizing dependencies has advantages for maintainability and interoperability, although my experience is that maintaining Julia is quite a bit easier than Python, because of the better package manager of Julia. The Julia ecosystem have more packages that are small, well-tested and built to synergize with other packages, and fewer giant monolith packages like Numpy or Scipy

text:
Keeping the code pure Julia certainly is a good idea. It has lots of good downstream consequences, like easier deployment and installation, easier debugging, and making it easier to contribute by Julia users. But it's not critical, really.
Finally, Julia objects have zero runtime costs, and often end up making your code faster because they compartmentalize your code such that optimizing parts of it is easier. The Julian way is to create tonnes of small new types.

elements.text:
Keeping the code pure Julia certainly is a good idea. It has lots of good downstream consequences, like easier deployment and installation, easier debugging, and making it easier to contribute by Julia users. But it's not critical, really.
Finally, Julia objects have zero runtime costs, and often end up making your code faster because they compartmentalize your code such that optimizing parts of it is easier. The Julian way is to create tonnes of small new types.

text: A good exercise is to have a toy project where you create small, low-level objects. Then you can convince yourself that types really do have zero runtime cost, and you can create a new type even for types that should be one byte in size.

elements.text: A good exercise is to have a toy project where you create small, low-level objects. Then you can convince yourself that types really do have zero runtime cost, and you can create a new type even for types that should be one byte in size.

Is this why _everything_ in Java is an object?

everything

text: Uh, ·∏Æm not familiar with Java. Types may not have zero overhead in Java. But they do for C++, Julia and Rust, certainly.

elements.text: Uh, ·∏Æm not familiar with Java. Types may not have zero overhead in Java. But they do for C++, Julia and Rust, certainly.

text: This is mind-boggling.  Man, I wish we could ditch Python except for glue code and just use Julia with neat little packages and types for the real programming.

elements.text: This is mind-boggling.  Man, I wish we could ditch Python except for glue code and just use Julia with neat little packages and types for the real programming.

text:
I have managed to do just that for my work, and it is incredible! Julia also have some drawbacks, particularly
‚Ä¢ The latency when starting up, which may be e.g. 15 seconds for scripts
‚Ä¢ Higher memory consumption due to the JIT compiler than more efficient languages like Rust
‚Ä¢ The language lacks good support for static analysis like other compiled languages have.

elements.text: I have managed to do just that for my work, and it is incredible! Julia also have some drawbacks, particularly
The latency when starting up, which may be e.g. 15 seconds for scripts
Higher memory consumption due to the JIT compiler than more efficient languages like Rust
The language lacks good support for static analysis like other compiled languages have.

text: *zero extra overhead compared to just allocating some memory and operating on it

elements.text: *zero extra overhead compared to just allocating some memory and operating on it

text: But if you use Python in situations where these drawbacks don't matter much, then switching to Julia is amazing

elements.text: But if you use Python in situations where these drawbacks don't matter much, then switching to Julia is amazing

text: Higher memory consumption can be alleviated by learning the ins and outs of `@benchmark` and `@code_warntype` ;)

@benchmark

text: Alright, time to start campaigning for Julia and Rust wherever I go.  I wonder if we could even re-implement the C++ of the reference implementations of Julia and the LLVM in Rust.

elements.text: Alright, time to start campaigning for Julia and Rust wherever I go.  I wonder if we could even re-implement the C++ of the reference implementations of Julia and the LLVM in Rust.

text: And to add support for static compilation, type checking, and Rust API calls to Julia.

elements.text: And to add support for static compilation, type checking, and Rust API calls to Julia.

text: static compilation works-ish right now with PackageCompiler.jl

elements.text: static compilation works-ish right now with PackageCompiler.jl

text: will be better in the future though, the past few months of compiler improvements have partially been in preparation for that

elements.text: will be better in the future though, the past few months of compiler improvements have partially been in preparation for that

text: Julia have rust API calls :) A rust re-impl will probably never happen, but the other things are a good idea!

elements.text: Julia have rust API calls :) A rust re-impl will probably never happen, but the other things are a good idea!

text: you can also call Rust from julia and julia from rust, iirc there were packages for both paths

text: reimplementing LLVM in Rust is probably not going to happen ever, LLVM has way too much buy-in from C++

elements.text: reimplementing LLVM in Rust is probably not going to happen ever, LLVM has way too much buy-in from C++

text: Yep!  Can‚Äôt wait for static compilation for those oddball cases that require hand-coding.  I wonder if now isn‚Äôt the perfect time to re-implement, though, because Rust‚Äôs inherent memory and type safety and legible syntax ease and hasten development.  We could have more new features sooner and faster with fewer bugs.

text: So, I do have another question.  Is Julia a good language for machine learning engineering?  I am an aspiring MLE who has been having way too much fun with it to want to use Python, which is apparently the industry standard.

elements.text: So, I do have another question.  Is Julia a good language for machine learning engineering?  I am an aspiring MLE who has been having way too much fun with it to want to use Python, which is apparently the industry standard.

text: Yes, it's excellent, almost perfect. But it doesn't yet have the high-quality massive packages like Pytorch. Those require massive amounts of developing effort.

elements.text: Yes, it's excellent, almost perfect. But it doesn't yet have the high-quality massive packages like Pytorch. Those require massive amounts of developing effort.

text: It's certainly catching up fast though

elements.text: It's certainly catching up fast though

text: there's also some exiting stuff on the horizon, which will make certain kinds of ML research much easier (NeuralODEs and the like are the magic words)

elements.text: there's also some exiting stuff on the horizon, which will make certain kinds of ML research much easier (NeuralODEs and the like are the magic words)

text: I bet that the actual silicon part of Silicon Valley is salivating over the multi-zillion-dollar opportunities to build custom hardware for all this stuff.

elements.text: I bet that the actual silicon part of Silicon Valley is salivating over the multi-zillion-dollar opportunities to build custom hardware for all this stuff.

text: Julia is actually written in multiple languages, Scheme (for the parsing and lowering code, using femtolisp, a very nice / small version of Scheme written by Jeff Bezanson), C++ (for the LLVM interface mostly, AFAICT), C (for the lowest level code, such as the dispatcher, GC, etc), and mostly, Julia itself.

elements.text: Julia is actually written in multiple languages, Scheme (for the parsing and lowering code, using femtolisp, a very nice / small version of Scheme written by Jeff Bezanson), C++ (for the LLVM interface mostly, AFAICT), C (for the lowest level code, such as the dispatcher, GC, etc), and mostly, Julia itself.

text: I‚Äôd love to see the parsing and lowering code reimplimented in Julia (but that does mean you need some older version of Julia around to build Julia), and the C code reimplemented in Rust :slightly_smiling_face:

elements.text: I‚Äôd love to see the parsing and lowering code reimplimented in Julia (but that does mean you need some older version of Julia around to build Julia), and the C code reimplemented in Rust

text: <@U01GC3N3ZJT> If you want to be stuck in the middle of a large herd of people using Python for ML, you can, but on the other hand, you could be at the forefront of things with Julia :slightly_smiling_face:

text: <@UB7JS9CHF> I would rather sit at the cool kids‚Äô table and use Julia, especially because I want to do new things rather than just maintain or expand old ones.  I love architecting, development, and green-field design but quickly grow bored with existing packages and legacy code bases, so if I can avoid cramming eleven different implementations of six different Python ML libraries from three different presidential administrations, then sign me up!
